title: When will it not be toxic to actually have a proper discussion about Lee Sin and what he represents?
body:
Seriously Riot, he is out the meta for 5 minutes and you immediately have to buff him to make him a top tier jungler again? Why can nobody even discuss this without a massive array of downvotes which prevents any worthwhile conversation about this champion?

{{champion:64}} has to only land one skillshot in order to do his combo. His ultimate is far too high in damage and does additional damage if it hits something else (another one of Riot's favouritism buffs). Why is this champion getting so much special treatment in League? 

I seriously would like to know if its me who thinks that Riot gives special treatment to certain champions or if other people have noticed this as well because its getting beyond a joke in my opinion. You might as well reduce the game down to 20+ Champions because thats all you seem to focus on. 

{{champion:64}} represents a worrying trend of a company that are too afraid to make meaningful changes to a champion that they know is either toxic/and/or/ broken. They tried to rework Lee Sin but the "rage" of the community stopped them. So far, that is the ONLY rework to be stopped, nobody else had that liberty.

This is like the third  or fourth Morde comment so far, what's with this Morde circle jerk?

He is probably one of their biggest failures as a rework. His changes didn't work for him thematically, it gave him an even unhealthier gameplay pattern, and he was way overpowered.

That combined with the massive backlash from the Morde community that was largely ignored makes him a very sore spot for a lot of players. The only part that they didn't mess up with him was his lore, which they were saved from a massive blunder by a community suggestion to change his title from "Lord of Death" to "The Iron Revenant".
Too bad riot didn't do it anyway like they have with several other reworks left in the dumpster.

Lee is one of the best examples of an argument I've made in the past:

"High Skill" - should not be a factor in a champs "power budget"

Lee has one of the games most overloaded kits, and he is not SO difficult that he should be allowed to have crazy stats along side his mobility, sustain  AND utility.

Yasuo very much falls into the same category, I'd argue that he's hard to LEARN; but once you understand his in's and outs, he's not really all that hard to play well. Once learned he has a kit that lets him work around virtually any opponent. With no resource beyond VERY short cool downs no less!  One tiny shift in meta breaks him, such as the recent tank yas fiasco, and DAMN if I didn't see a lot of mechanically TERRIBLE Yasuo's carry games when the original iteration of "Warlord's Bloodlust" first released with the keystone mastery re-work!

If Evelynn's passive fills enough of her "power budget" to justify nerfing the rest of her kit and stats into the dirt.... And Poppy had to lose a lot of damage AND utility because she wasn't being played "as we intended"... WHY are these two not allowed to be anything short of A-tier!?

I may be saying some bullshit but it may have to do with the fact that unlike Poppy or Eve, they are considered fun to play, and are popular. Riot knows that if they give the Yorick treatment to Lee and Yasuo, it will be a very, very big shitfest. Not to mention, they tend to sell a lot of skins. And you know what happens when there is money involved into it.

So they try to mantain both of them weak, but not to the point that Yorick used to be.
I find Poppy way more fun than Yasuo, and Riot destroyed her for basically no reason.  She was already nerfed into a decent state, but the nerfs kept on coming.

I don't understand why they took away the AA reset. That only made her feel incredibly clunky. 

I'd like to know the _reason_ why they took it, but I fear the reason is, "We're just taking away stuff until we feel her power is fine. We have no idea if her AA reset will help with that but it seems like something we should try removing."

I don't even care about the ranged nerfs (they hurt but I suppose I can adapt). But the removal of the AA reset made her jungle clears much slower. To the point where it feels detrimental to actually play her in the jungle. 

And don't tell me, "She's designed only for top" when her champion reveal page literally has a _section on her jungling_. 

 
http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/page/champion-update-poppy-keeper-hammer

"but the tiny tussler is designed to be a powerful roaming jungle in her own right."

So why Riot?  Why did you basically destroy her tank jungling?!
I loved Poppy jungle.  Like I said, they didn't just nerf her, they pulled an Akali and killed the fluidity.

> unlike Poppy or Eve, they are considered fun to play, and are popular.

Fun is relative, and popularity is often controlled and influenciatedby Riot. For example: Old Karma was ''unpopular'' but only because Riot banned her from the game basically.

Trust me when I tell you that I hate Lee Sin. Like, I **really** hate Lee Sin.

The reason that Riot balances Lee the way that they do is because when Lee Sin isn't strong it weakens the game's early pressure. Rek'Sai has lost most of her damage and most other AD junglers (except Kha'Zix) don't have Lee's mobility early game to get successful kills off ganks at higher levels. 

Nidalee is certainly a strong early jungler as well, but she's AP. You need an AD and an AP of the same threat to be more flexible in your team comp selection.

If Lee Sin isn't strong, then tank junglers become too powerful, and when tank junglers are too powerful, it makes assassins in the mid lane worse, which means that marksmen have no one to kill them and the entire game's ecosystem kind of falls apart.

Lee Sin has to be strong enough to be a threat. As long as Lee is a powerful champion, he artificially lowers the amount of tank junglers in the game, because a tank jungler will be hesitant to blind pick their tank jungler if Lee Sin isn't banned. 

That's why Lee has to be relevant in every meta.
Then... what about nerfing Marksmen instead? They seem to be the root of this entire issue after all.
It is much easier to bring one champion into viability rather than bringing ten into nothing.
Easier doesn't mean better.
